reviewText: The art, style, music and atmosphere of this game are amazing. The game itself tells a subtle story about two simple characters that are looking to gain their freedom, while being watched by a being called the Prism. The game itself plays nicely, eases you into levels while slowly increasing difficulty. The story tells itself in a subtle way, explaining what has happened before and who the characters are. The music and artwork create a very calm atmosphere, with beautiful environments. As the game progresses you lose and unlock different abilities, which makes the game's playstyle and content constantly move around and change. Overall this game is great, could use a little tweaking when it comes to options menu's though.\n\nI give it a solid 8.5/10

reviewText:
THE PRISM REVIEW
Looking at the current reviews for this game leaves me more puzzled as when I played the game. Why does this game have mixed reviews? (at the time I wrote this)

This review is written with currently only 1.5 hours put into the game. I have quite liked so far of what I have played and figured I would give it a quick review.
So far what I have played makes me realize how under-rated this game really is. This is a one of a kind puzzle game that I have not seen anything like before.
I'm usually a total newbie when it comes to puzzle games but The Prism was simple enough at the start for me to pick up as well as constantly introducing new level elements as the game progressed.

Gameplay
The main gameplay of The Prism is you controlling two cubes. As long as one of those two cubes reaches the exit then you progress.
The creator claims its similar to the game 'Thomas was Alone' and I have to agree with them. It is quite similar to that game.
There are some levels that feature new random mechanics that come into play for only that level. This keeps the game interesting and I honestly like that a whole lot, even though you may never see those mechanics again.

There are some issues with the collision detection however as sometimes, '02' and '03' can get stuck in each other if you make them jump into each other.
This is only a minor issue however, it doesn't take away much from the game.
Also the resolution seems to be all over the place between levels, The game auto stretches to your native resolution but its obvious when you change levels.

The puzzles in the game are very well crafted. None of the puzzles seem rushed and they all feel very different to each other.
The level design feels like it always features one new thing" that you get to play with or over come.
Be it making a bridge out of lying cubes or flying through valleys in a 'Helicopter'-esque mini-game. 'The Prism' always feels fresh.

Story
There is very little story to The Prism
date:
you are just spawned into the game and left to figure it out.
There are some hints at some story but nothing is given to you at the start to give you a hint to the story.
You just play as cube '02' and '03' and help them progress.

Even if there is little to no story
recommended: I cant help but feel for the little guys.\nI WANT them to get through the levels and progress forward. I cant even explain why because they are just little cubes.\nAgain
hoursPlayed:
this is similar to 'Thomas was Alone'.

Audio
The soundtrack to the prism is absolutely stunning. If anyone knows me well
voteText: they will know that I ♥♥♥♥ing love music and a games soundtrack is something I almost certainly hunt down.\nThe Prism's soundtrack was done by 'MISTER STRANGE' and it is very atmospheric. It leaves me simply enchanted because of just how calm it is.\nThe music fits in almost perfectly with the game
helpfulPercent: it matches the visuals perfectly as the locations you take place in
votesHelpful:
you could imagine them actually sounding like the soundtrack.
This is a damn good sign of a damn good soundtrack.

The soundtrack can be found on Soundcloud  here! [soundcloud.com]
votesTotal:
You should totally check it out.

Where I do think the soundtrack is perfect. What is there is very limited. There is only 6 songs and they repeat maybe too often.
If there was a couple more songs that would change every now and again
commentsCount:
then it would be a 10/10 perfect.

Visuals
Okay this game looks STUNNING. The game feels like the developer crafted each and every frame with extreme precision as every little detail looks gorgeous.
Each and every environment in this game bursts with vibrant colors

Final Overview
So in overall
column22: The Prism is a puzzle platformer that I feel is incredibly underrated on steam. Its another case of a game being misrepresented by its reviews.\nWhere I cant say that the other reviews are wrong

column24: but my opinion on the game is that it is pretty god damn good.\nThe visuals and the audio fit together perfectly

reviewText:
6/10 - Good? Yes. $10? Don't make me laugh.

The game is pretty good; I do recommend this game at a highly discounted price! The ambiance of the game is definitely the best part, the maps were well done and the music added to the tranquil pixel puzzler experience.

You play as 2 blocks that must assist each other in accomplishing levels. The gameplay is simple but challenging. There is a storyline but it was too sparse for me to care or comprehend. You must use duel pads/keys to play this game, which I really enjoy; shows some serious potential with the steam controller!

The biggest issue for me honestly is the price; for just $5 more you could grab Brothers; which is basically the same concept but on steroids, and way better! I would have rated this higher if not for humorous price tag.

Worth $2-4; pretty sure I got it in a bundle for less.

reviewText: Honestly, I don't understand how anyone could say this game is bad. I was blown away. The beautiful art style, atmosphere and music are incredible. The puzzles get increasingly difficult, although it starts off a bit slow. This game doesn't get enough attention and is WAAAAAAAAAAY underrated. Too much haters on steam.\n\n

reviewText: The art and visual style are awesome.  Great atmosphere.  I wish I could say the same for the gameplay and puzzle design.  It's just really basic and uninspiring.  It seems like the game is really meant for 2 player coop becuse for 1 person it's more frustrating than fun.

reviewText: What makes this game really fun to play is the great atmosphere that's created with the looks of the environment in addition to the music which work together very well. It can also be very challenging which I personally, really like. Overall, it is a very good game worth purchasing and checking out.
Quite an interesting game. The arts style is amazing, and the music is awesome. The puzzles are pretty simple so far. Overall, the gameplay is awesome.

This puzzle platformer puts the player in control of a pair of runaway pixels.  Technically they look like at least 256 pixels cubes.  Each controlled with a different position on the keyboard to allow both to move independently.

https://youtu.be/tiLZqJN1C-w

The visual style of this game is simple but the high contrast makes it enjoyable.  The lack of visual cues for dangers will cause some frustration.

However, the greatest frustration factor is the controls and surface detection.  This finicky combination can result in missed input resulting in pixel death.

Occasionally the game will ask the player to hold keys down to manipulate the pixels to progress through levels.  This is an attempt of physicality to add weight to the actions of the pixels, that they can't be ignored.  Regrettably, the end result is more tedium than empathy.

reviewText: The art and the music are the main stand outs of the game. It has a strong atmosphere and characters. The puzzles were challenging and some of the cool powers I got were really cool. The overall story is quite simple, yet really deep and emotional. The music really sets those emotions too. I would definitely recommend this game.
